# PhysicsBodyComponent

**Structure**

A component that defines an entity’s behavior in physics body simulations.

## Declaration

```swift
struct PhysicsBodyComponent
```

## Overview

Only entities with a [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicsBodyComponent] and a [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/CollisionComponent] can participate in a scene’s physics simulation. If you need to move an entity that participates in the physics system, it also needs a [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicsMotionComponent].

Add a physics body component to an entity by adopting the [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/HasPhysicsBody] protocol, which allows RealityKit’s physics simulation to compute behavior in response to forces acting upon the body, following basic rules of Newtonian mechanics.

Note the following when considering applying a non-uniform scale to an entity:

- Non-uniform scaling is applicable only to box, convex mesh and triangle mesh collision shapes.
- Non-uniform scaling is not supported for all other types of collision shapes. In this case the scale.x value is duplicated to the scale’s y and z components as well to force scale uniformity based on the x component.
- If the entity has a non-uniform scale assigned to its transform then that entity should not have any descendants assigned that contain rotations in their transforms. A good rule of thumb is to assign the non-uniform scale to the entity that has the collision shape, and avoid adding children below that entity.



## Creating a physics body component

- **init()**: Creates a physics body component with default settings.
- **init(massProperties:material:mode:)**: Creates a physics body component with the given mass properties, material, and mode.
- **init(shapes:density:material:mode:)**: Creates a physics body component deriving mass properties from shape and density.
- **init(shapes:mass:material:mode:)**: Creates a physics body component deriving mass properties from shape and mass.

## Detecting collisions

- **isContinuousCollisionDetectionEnabled**: A Boolean that controls whether the physics simulation performs continuous collision detection.

## Locking movement

- **isRotationLocked**: A tuple of Boolean values that you use to lock rotation of the physics body around any of the three axes.
- **isTranslationLocked**: A tuple of Boolean values that you use to lock the position of the physics body along any of the three axes.

## Setting the mode

- **mode**: The behavioral mode that controls the way the physics body moves and interacts with other physics bodies in a simulation.

## Setting material properties

- **material**: The physics body’s material properties, like friction.

## Setting mass properties

- **massProperties**: The physics body’s mass properties, like inertia and center of mass.

## Comparing physics body components

- **==(_:_:)**: Indicates whether two physics body components are equal.

## Instance Properties

- **angularDamping**: The value that controls how fast a dynamic rigid body’s rotational motion approaches the zero rest state.
- **isAffectedByGravity**: A Boolean value that indicates whether gravity acts on dynamic rigid bodies.
- **linearDamping**: The value that controls how fast a dynamic rigid body’s translation motion approaches the zero rest state.

## Physical properties

- **PhysicsMaterialResource**: Material properties, like friction, of a physically simulated object.
- **PhysicsBodyMode**: The ways that a physics body can move in response to physical forces.
- **PhysicsMassProperties**: Mass properties of a physics body.

## Conforms To

- Component
- Equatable
